column4: Question: Postgresql: How to change user password with password prompt, securely?
ALTER ROLE myuser WITH PASSWORD 'hu8jmn3'; BUT it's sent in clear-text, not secure
I understood that command and am aware of the clear text problem.  I'm googling about it, and haven't found an answer yet.
i think you might be able to do this: "ALTER ROLE myuser WITH ENCRYPTED PASSWORD 'md5-of-password'"
how do I get the md5-of-password?
It is surprising that something this simple is not implemented or can be easily found out.
online service, one of many: http://www.md5.cz/
you could also make a simple script to do it
jwrigley : Specifically how do I integrate the md5 generation digest within the psql command line mode.
if you're using psql, why don't you just use /password? :s
I guess I could.  Just wondering if SQL-standard command covers it.
i don't know if it's random or blank, but you can log in only locally using Ident (e.g. using sudo -u postgresql psql) until you set a new password
that's what I do.  But just curious.
it would be wrong to allow outside access to your pg server without any password :)
I have read that ident could also pose security risk, and there are suggestion to change mode to md5 in the hba.conf file and restart postgresql.
i don't see how it could be a security risk, but maybe someone from #postgresql can answer to that
I do not know exact details either.  I'm still learning and exploring.  :-0
